description.narrative:
International Media Service(IMS) has been supporting independent media in Afghanistan since 2008. Sida´s support started 2012. To support the Afghan media in fulfilling its role in the country´s fragile democratic process their focus are on: - Creating a safe environment for journalists through a locally anchored safety mechanism that combines training, practical measures and advocacy. - Improving the levels of professional journalism among media workers, enabling them to support citizen´s ability to take part in the country´s democratic process. - Engaging authorities across Afghanistan to protect media and support Freedom of Expression.
The Afghan Journalist´s Safety Committee (AJSC) set up by IMS is the first organisation of its kind in Afghanistan, which includes press unions, media representatives and civil society organisations. The AJSC facilitates a continuous dialogue with the Afghan government on media safety. A countrywide safety mechanism run by Afghan Journalists´ Safety Committee covers 32 out of 34 provinces and monitors incidents and provides journalists with advice and practical safety measures. A 24/7 hotline is available for journalists in peril. The hotline provides emergency support; legal and medical assistance and relocation; and training activities. Female journalists are provided with special assistance through dedicates female safety coordinators and safety training. Approximately 700 journalists have received training in risk management, physical and online safety , first aid, conflict sensibility and photo journalism since 2009. The safety has successfully advocated for the inclusion of two provisions on the safety of journalists in Afghanistan´s new draft media law. The provisions underline the government´s responsibility for the safety of journalists.
Key intervention objectives during 2014-2016 are: Safety for Afghan workers has been improved, particularly for female workers. The media reports more professionally on transitional issues in an ethical, balanced and conflict sensitive manner, particularly during elections. Freedom of Expression and information laws passed and supported by key opinion makers. safety for Afghan media workers has been improved, in particular for female journalists.

International Media Support (IMS) har stött oberoende media i Afghanistan sedan 2008. Sida har bidragit med stöd till IMS sedan 2012. För att afghansk media ska kunna fullgöra sin roll i landets svaga demokratiska process har IMS fokuserat på: - Skapa skyddsåtgärder för journalister genom lokala förankrade skyddsmekanismer med en kombination av utbildning, praktiska åtgärder och upplysningsverksamhet. Förbättra den professionella nivån på journalister och uppmuntra dem att stödja medborgarnas deltagande i landets demokratiska process. Engagera beslutsfattare runt om i Afghanistan att bidra till skydd av media och stödja yttrandefrihet.
Afghanska journalisters säkerhetskommitté (AJSC) som har byggts upp av IMS är den första av sitt slag i Afghanistan och omfattar press-fackföreningar, media representanter och organisationer från civila samhället. AJCS bidrar till en fortlöpande dialog med afghanska regeringen om säkerhet för media.
En landsomfattande skyddsmekanism som AJSC driver täcker 32 av landets 34 provinser. AJSC följer upp händelser och ger rådgivning till journalister om mediaskydd och praktiska skyddsåtgärder.
En 24/7 hotline jourtelefon finns tillgänglig för journalister som befinner sig i fara. Genom jourtelefonen kan drabbade journalister få stöd i akuta situationer, få lagligt och medicinsk stöd samt utbildning insatser. Kvinnliga journalister får särskilt stöd genom en kvinnlig säkerhhetssamordnare och genom säkerhetsutbildning. Omkring 700 journalister har utbildats i riskhantering, fysiska och psykiska säkerhetsåtgärder, första hjälpen, konfliktkänslighet samt fotojournalistik sedan 2009. Säkerhetskommitteen har lyckats få in två paragrafer om säkerhet för jornalister i utkastet till Afghanistans nya medialagstiftning. Paragraferna understryker regeringens ansvar för säkerhet av journalister.

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The programme’s overall objective is to contribute to the Afghan public being better informed and to be able to voice their concerns in the transitional process at the national and local levels, and thus being able to report on the democratic development. This entails good and ethical journalism being carried out in a safe environment to contribute to informed citizens and leaders to contribute to a peaceful and democratic development. During this period, some 500 journalists in distress have been supported, and practical safety measures have been provided across the 34 provinces. 600 journalists (out of which 25% women) have been trained in safety practices, risk management, and conflict sensitive training. Furthermore, the programme has continued its advocacy work, and to actively ensure and strengthen the continued dialogue between media and the Afghan government, national authorities and international partners.
